results.title: Happy little Vegemites = Cheap rush
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Dead Head Films and Colin Mowbray
results.brief_description: A furiously energetic short film about young homeless people who spend a night in emergency accommodation. They are bored and decide to search for some speed. When their efforts prove fruitless one of them decides that maybe a dose of vegemite might to the trick! With an excellent young cast and tight scripting, “Happy Little Vegemites” manages to be both comic, and in the scenes between the naive Gerard and the streetwise Chad, effectively touching. Features an excellent music track including Radiohead, Beasts of Bourbon and Rebecca’s Empire. Be warned, vegemite may never look the same again!

results.title: Happiness Is Loving Your Teacher
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Vladimir Valenta and John Smith
results.brief_description: A crippled substitute teacher has great difficulty controlling a class of students, especially a girl called Toni. Kept in detention, Toni walks out after verbally attacking the teacher. Next day, as the normal teacher has returned, the substitute teacher does not have to face the class. A repentant Toni rings him up and makes them both feel better. Stars Marina Dimakopoulos, Martin Kevin. Written by Mariette Cook, John N. Smith.

results.title: Happiness Is
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Gaston Sarault and Clorinda Warny
results.brief_description: For a young mother happiness can be an hour’s stroll in the park with her sleeping infant—but happiness is short-lived when the baby begins to cry and the passers-by pause with freely proffered advice. Made of animated paper cut-outs, this film without words is a spoof about the self-styled child experts who are so caught up with their own views of what’s best for a child that they fail to see the infant’s real problem.

results.title: Happiness [Widescreen] (E)
results.creator_credit: Good Machine International, Killer Films, Ted Hope, Christine Vachon and Todd Solondz
results.brief_description: This controversial and darkly funny independent film is an examination of the alienated lives of three middle-class sisters. The eldest (Elizabeth Ashley) believes herself to be happily married and the epitome of suburban success, but she is unaware that her psychiatrist husband lusts after his son’s school-boy friends; the middle sister (Lara Flynn Boyle) is an emotionally sterile successful writer who is fascinated by the obscene phonecalls of her next door neighbour; and the youngest (Jane Adams) is an eternally optimistic hippie who maintains a Candide-like faith in her fellow humans and therefore ends up being taken advantage of by family, friends and colleagues. Populated by a cast of talented character actors, “Happiness” is a sharply scripted film that explores the break-down of family life and community. By focussing on sexual relationships that mainstream English-language cinema usually only presents as evil or extreme, the film also manages to present the underlying loneliness that leads to the bleakness and alienation of modern suburban life. In its final devastating scenes, the film also manages to convey powerfully, and unexpectedly, the importance of familial relationships. Often criticised as cynical, the reality is that in its final moments, “Happiness” reveals itself as a compassionate and moving film. Cast includes Ben Gazzara, Louise Lasser, Phillip Seymour Hoffman and Cynthia Stevenson.

results.title: Happily unmarried
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Radford, Lorna Rasmussen and Anne Wheeler
results.brief_description: Joyce Rasmussen and her 25-year-old daughter Lorna have both chosen to live without partners. Joyce is divorced; Lorna has chosen to remain single. But they are friends and they talk openly about coping as “singles” in this couple-oriented society, and about their attitudes on such issues as monogamy and collective households.

results.title: Hanussen
results.creator_credit: Objektiv Filmstudio Vallalat, CCC Filmkunst, Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen, Hungarofilm, Arthur Brauner and Istvan Szabo
results.brief_description: Hanussen is the third in a sumptuous film trilogy by Istvan Szabo, concerning Central Europe between the fall of the Austro-Hungarian Empire and the prelude to WWII. All three star the charismatic Austrian actor Klaus Maria Brandauer as individuals in whom the tragic contradictions of the period are brought to a crisis. In Hanussen he is an Austrian corporal wounded in the head during WWI, who then finds he has the power to foresee the rise of Nazism, but trivialises his powers as a hypnotist until his final downfall. Nominated for an Academy Award as best foreign film.
